g.text: Beilstein J. Nanotechnol.
Figure 1:
Topological phase and characterization of 1T’-WTe
. a) Side and top views of lattice structures of 1T’-WTe
. Brown spheres: tellurium
atoms, blue spheres: tungsten atoms. b) XPS spectrum of W 4f (green line) and Te 3d (red line) peaks. c) TEM image and SEAD pattern of WTe
revealing the crystal structure of the 1T’ phase, with lattice parameters
a
3.49 Å and
b
6.32 Å, respectively. d) Raman spectrum of a 1T’-WTe
flake.
discovery of its large non-saturating positive magnetoresistance
(MR) behavior, which was attributed to its perfect electron–hole
compensation. Theoretical calculations and experiments have
indicated that WTe
has a complicated electronic structure with
more than two bands presenting at the Fermi level [17]. Mean-
while, it was believed to a wonderful candidate for the type-II
Weyl semimetal [18] and quantum spin Hall insulator material
[19]. Additionally, many other remarkable properties of WTe
have also been revealed, such as the temperature-driven Lifshitz
transition [20], pressure-induced superconductivity [21], linear
Nernst response [22], etc. Interestingly, although all of the
TMDCs have the same formula, the atomic structure of 1T’-
phase WTe
is totally different from the other TMDCs. 1T’-
WTe
exhibits a distorted structure relative to the 1T’ phase.
Both Raman [23,24] and first-principles [25,26] calculations
have been used to indicate that monolayer 1T’-WTe
has a
highly in-plane anisotropic crystal structure, in addition to
anisotropic electrical, thermal and optical properties [23-26].
However, most of the results are based on theoretical demon-
strations of the anisotropic phenomenon, rather than further
quantitative data for the characterization the natural anisotropy
of 1T’-WTe
In this paper, we present a combined experimental and quantita-
tive study on the anisotropic optical and electronic properties of
mechanically isolated 1T’-WTe
. Through a systematic charac-
terization including Raman spectroscopy, X-ray photoelectron
spectroscopy and azimuth-dependent reflectance difference
microscopy (ADRDM), we firstly identified the 1T’-phase
WTe
to have an optical anisotropic crystal structure. Secondly,
a 12-electrode-structure was designed for the evaluation the
electrical anisotropy of 1T’-WTe
, and the results demon-
strated up to 10
times relative electrical anisotropy. Subse-
quently, the photo-electrical conductance was studied to further
explore the anisotropic photo-electric property. Our results
revealed an anisotropic photo-electrical conductance with a
maximum ratio of 4.33 among the 12 directions. Finally, a
photodetector with twelve electrodes was used to distinguish
the different wavelengths in the visible spectrum, demon-
strating that 1T’-WTe
shows promising application as an
anisotropic photodetector.
Results and Discussion
Characterization of 1T’- WTe
Figure 1a shows the typical orthorhombic crystalline structure
of 1T’-WTe
. The tungsten atoms deviate from the ideal octa-
hedral sites in the octahedron due to the very strong chemical
bonding, forming the distorted octahedral structure. Conse-
quently, the Te atom layers become buckled in the distorted oc-
tahedral structure.
